description: From Middle English *foredemen, from Old English foredēman (“to prejudge”), equivalent to fore- +‎ deem.

verbs.description: foredeem (third-person singular simple present foredeems, present participle foredeeming, simple past and past participle foredeemed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To judge, form a judgement of, or declare beforehand; foretell; forecast; presage.
examples: Which [maid] could guess and foredeem of things past, present, and to come.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deem or account in advance; consider; take for granted; expect.
examples: And of a beste, then fordeme the worst frende it was more standing with humanitee and gentlenesse to hope the best, then to foredeme the worste
